    When Angular was first released in 2010 by Google, it was revolutionary. It came with two-way data binding, dependency injection and brought modular architecture to the table. Today Angular is thriving with each new version released, refining and improving the framework and maturing like fine wine. 🤩

Angular is one of our trusted tools in our solution development toolbox. Why do we love using it with our client’s? Here are a few reasons why:

✅ It’s reliable and our developers know what to expect when using it.
✅ Angular’s community is strong and always growing, which means there’s always someone to lend a hand when you’re troubleshooting an issue.
✅ Angular offers a fully-equipped toolbox that makes development much easier for our team.
✅ The possibilities are endless for Angular from small websites or large enterprise solutions for our clients.

Interested in learning more about Angular and what it can do for your business? Reach out to us to get the conversation started at hello@thinkingbig.net.

#webdev #softwaredevelopment #websitedevelopment #development #CMS #drupal #webcontentmanagement #enterprisetools #enterprise #CRM #CRMdev #dynamics #microsoft #angular

    Retrospectives are a key part of our team’s projects. 🔑

They provide a structured space for our teams to reflect on their recent work, celebrate their success and identify opportunities for improvement. By fostering open communication and honest feedback, retrospectives enable our teams to have continuous refinement of processes and practices. These sessions are a key tool for TBers to iterate on their practices, ensuring they evolve and deliver value more effectively over time within the Agile framework.

Here’s how to make your next retrospective impactful:

✅ Documentation: Record the essential insights and findings from your retros using tools like Miro or Figjam for your team to reference as you work on identified opportunities for your team’s improvement.

✅ Prioritization: Rank the identified findings based on their impact on the project and ease of implementation. Address the most critical issues first to maximize the impact of improvements.

✅ Define & Assign: For each finding, clearly outline action items to address or enhance the situation. Specify what needs to change, who is responsible, and the expected outcomes. Assign responsibilities for implementing the identified actions. Communicate roles and responsibilities clearly to ensure everyone is aware of their part in the improvement process.

✅ Monitor & Reflect: Regularly track the progress of your action items and assess whether the desired improvements are being realized. Gather continuous feedback from team members through future reflections during retros to evaluate whether the improvements your team is making are making their desired impact.

    Services vs Providers, what’s the difference? 🛠️

In code bases, Services and Providers may seem similar, but they serve distinct purposes:

Providers
👉 Abstractions of external dependencies (e.g., APIs, File Systems).
👉 Highly specific with a focused interface.
👉 Contain no application logic; designed for encapsulating dependencies.

Services
👉 Home to application logic, often as monolithic modules or use case handlers.
👉 Interact with various components (databases, providers, event systems).
👉 Scoped in Dependency Injection (DI) for broader application use.

Clear separation between Providers (technical abstraction) and Services (application logic) is crucial. Providers abstract dependencies, while Services handle application-specific tasks. Stick to these principles in your architecture for robust code. 🔨

#CodeArchitecture #ServiceProviderPattern #BestPractices #thinkingbig #UXdesign #UIdesign #appdesign #appdevelopment #softwaredevelopment #webdev #websitedevelopment #development #CMS #drupal #webcontentmanagement #enterprisetools #enterprise #CRM #CRMdev #dynamics #microsoft #api

    Designing powerful digital products is like crafting a captivating story! 📖

1️⃣ Every Page is the Beginning:

Design with users in mind, considering their entry point and context. Just like a TV show recaps past episodes, each page should remind users why they're here. Changes in the process? Provide clear context to guide even the most seasoned users.

2️⃣ Mad Max - Center Framed:

Imagine your web journey as a Mad Max movie – keep the focus! Quick clicks between pages should feel natural. Maintain flow continuity for a smooth user experience. Objects in your design have actions – make them obvious. Users are editors; help them navigate by creating unique experiences on each page.

3️⃣ Continuity Between Pages:

Each web page is a new film, with changing plots but consistent characters. Like Batman movies, users should recognize elements without needing a tutorial. Implicit understanding is key – users shouldn't need explanations with every page. Think Batman – you always know his backstory!

4️⃣ Final Take-Aways:

Multiple paths lead to the same destination. Users march to their own beat; don't expect them to follow your script. Design for flexibility; users should seamlessly start from any point. Introduce new elements with context; keep users from guessing halfway through.

Remember, users are the heroes of their journeys – design for an engaging and exciting experience at every click! 💻

    Creating valuable content for your digital products begins with understanding your audience and their objectives. Content generated without careful consideration tends to be needlessly lengthy. 

In the realm of content planning and writing, formatting and structuring are intertwined. Formatting guarantees content predictability and scanability, while structuring establishes an organizational approach for efficient content delivery. Prioritize strategic content structuring before implementing formatting to ensure logical and coherent presentation. A well-designed content structure aids users in forming a clear mental model of the page, making it easier for them to navigate your content. 

Here are 5 formatting techniques for your content:

✅ Summaries: Using a summary of your content gives your users the key points from your information and allows them to decide if your content is relevant to them or not quickly.
✅ Callouts: A callout refers to a paragraph that is formatted to stand out from the rest of the body text. Callouts leverage visual weight to attract readers’ attention.
✅ Bullet points: They support scanning, emphasize key points, and reveal relationships among items. Bullet points can be paired with in-page links to serve as a table of contents for the page.
✅ Bolding and highlighting key points: Bolding and highlighting should be used to call attention to critical information.
✅ Helpful visuals: Using visuals helps break up walls of text and diversify the content layout, allowing eyes to rest from reading.

Want to learn more about formatting your content? Check out this article by the NNgroup here: https://buff.ly/3UcaLSA

    When life presents us with choices, we often find ourselves caught in the tug-of-war between two seemingly opposing options. It’s like being stuck at a crossroads, unsure whether to go left or right. But what if I told you that this binary either/or thinking might not be the best approach. Our tendency to view things in black and white limits our perspective and inhibits creativity. Surprisingly a list of pros and cons isn’t going to take us far in figuring out the best way to go. The solution lies in understanding that there are new ways of thinking that unlock innovation by embracing the nuances between that black-and-white perspective. 🧐

Read our article about embracing the grey and breaking free from binary thinking here: https://buff.ly/3U81rPI

    We know, team meetings suck. But what if they didn’t have to? 💩

The key to facilitating a good team meeting can be broken down into 4 key elements. Master these and you’ll have your team members asking when your next meeting is!

📌 Objective: Clearly define the purpose of your meeting. Determine your team’s desired goals and outcomes from the meeting, whether they’re big or small.

📌 Agenda: Create a meeting agenda. This structure will keep you organized and help you follow up your meeting with action items once it’s over, providing clarity and accountability from your team.

📌 Engagement: Avoid delivering monologues during team meetings, as active engagement is key to a successful gathering. Foster an environment where team members actively participate, and ensure that everyone remains present and attentive.

📌 Details: Consider the timing of your meetings and carefully select attendees. Strategic planning of when and who participates is just as pivotal as crafting a well-thought-out agenda and objectives.

Do you run amazing meetings? Share your meeting tips with us! 📢

    We love using the game-changing feature in C# 12 - the Primary Constructor! You can define a constructor directly in the class declaration, making your code cleaner and more concise. 🤓

It's a game-changer for defining immutable types. But here's the catch - while it's a great step forward, the compiler doesn't enforce parameter immutability. 😬

Fear not! Here are two solutions:

Solution 1: Using a read-only field. This involves creating a read-only field with the same name as the parameter and assigning the parameter value to the field. A bit of boilerplate, but effective.

Solution 2: Enter the stage, Roslyn analyzer!  You can use Meziantou. Analyzer to catch cases where a parameter is being assigned. Once installed, the rule MA0143 will report all assignments to primary constructor parameters in your project or usages as ref or out parameters. 

You can learn more about primary constructors here: https://buff.ly/42eYQW5

    Our TB crew is chalked full of talented folks doing cool things. Have you heard of @freefromtheharbour ?

Brianne Savage and Meryn Avery are two best friends from the Maritimes who will be rowing 3000 miles across the Atlantic Ocean in 2025. They are set to be the first all-Canadian female pair ever to attempt the crossing and are raising money for the Marine Animal Response Society along the way. 🐳

To raise money and awareness for their campaign, they are hosting a screening of the documentary, Losing Sight of Shore, a film about four women whose journey to row across the Pacific Ocean inspired Brianne and Meryn to do it themselves. Join them on Sunday, February 11th to learn more about the extreme sport of ocean rowing and meet the team! 

You can learn more about their endeavour and follow their journey at https://buff.ly/4b5uOZ6

    How can Service Design help my organization?

Service Design can help your organization by placing your users at the center of your strategy, fostering innovation, improving efficiency, and creating a more adaptable and user-centered product. By blending your user’s needs with your organization’s, you can truly take your product to the next level.

How does it work?

🗺 Discovery: This phase allows us to better understand your users, their needs and how they work within the context of your organization’s needs. 

🔧 Prototyping: During this time we take those requirements and needs and turn them into visual solutions.

👍 Validation: Once we have prototypes, we need to validate our designs with your users.

It’s important to note that these phases are iterative! Taking an iterative approach allows us to prototype and validate your solutions continuously until we reach a final design that meets all of your user’s needs and organization’s requirements.

Want to learn more about how Service Design can take your organization to the next level? Shoot us a message at hello@thinkingbig.net 📬

When Angular was first released in 2010 by Google, it was revolutionary. It came with two-way data binding, dependency injection and brought modular architecture to the table. Today Angular is thriving with each new version released, refining and improving the framework and maturing like fine wine. 🤩 Angular is one of our trusted tools in our solution development toolbox. Why do we love using it with our client’s? Here are a few reasons why: ✅ It’s reliable and our developers know what to expect when using it. ✅ Angular’s community is strong and always growing, which means there’s always someone to lend a hand when you’re troubleshooting an issue. ✅ Angular offers a fully-equipped toolbox that makes development much easier for our team. ✅ The possibilities are endless for Angular from small websites or large enterprise solutions for our clients. Interested in learning more about Angular and what it can do for your business? Reach out to us to get the conversation started at hello@thinkingbig.net. #webdev #softwaredevelopment #websitedevelopment #development #CMS #drupal #webcontentmanagement #enterprisetools #enterprise #CRM #CRMdev #dynamics #microsoft #angular

    Retrospectives are a key part of our team’s projects. 🔑 They provide a structured space for our teams to reflect on their recent work, celebrate their success and identify opportunities for improvement. By fostering open communication and honest feedback, retrospectives enable our teams to have continuous refinement of processes and practices. These sessions are a key tool for TBers to iterate on their practices, ensuring they evolve and deliver value more effectively over time within the Agile framework. Here’s how to make your next retrospective impactful: ✅ Documentation: Record the essential insights and findings from your retros using tools like Miro or Figjam for your team to reference as you work on identified opportunities for your team’s improvement. ✅ Prioritization: Rank the identified findings based on their impact on the project and ease of implementation. Address the most critical issues first to maximize the impact of improvements. ✅ Define & Assign: For each finding, clearly outline action items to address or enhance the situation. Specify what needs to change, who is responsible, and the expected outcomes. Assign responsibilities for implementing the identified actions. Communicate roles and responsibilities clearly to ensure everyone is aware of their part in the improvement process. ✅ Monitor & Reflect: Regularly track the progress of your action items and assess whether the desired improvements are being realized. Gather continuous feedback from team members through future reflections during retros to evaluate whether the improvements your team is making are making their desired impact. #thinkingbig #UXdesign #UIdesign #appdesign #appdevelopment #softwaredevelopment #webdev #softwaredevelopment #websitedevelopment #development #agile #backlog #productbacklog #userstories #agileteam #sprintplanning #scrummaster #retro #retrospectives #scrumceremony #scrummeeting

    Services vs Providers, what’s the difference? 🛠️ In code bases, Services and Providers may seem similar, but they serve distinct purposes: Providers 👉 Abstractions of external dependencies (e.g., APIs, File Systems). 👉 Highly specific with a focused interface. 👉 Contain no application logic; designed for encapsulating dependencies. Services 👉 Home to application logic, often as monolithic modules or use case handlers. 👉 Interact with various components (databases, providers, event systems). 👉 Scoped in Dependency Injection (DI) for broader application use. Clear separation between Providers (technical abstraction) and Services (application logic) is crucial. Providers abstract dependencies, while Services handle application-specific tasks. Stick to these principles in your architecture for robust code. 🔨 #CodeArchitecture #ServiceProviderPattern #BestPractices #thinkingbig #UXdesign #UIdesign #appdesign #appdevelopment #softwaredevelopment #webdev #websitedevelopment #development #CMS #drupal #webcontentmanagement #enterprisetools #enterprise #CRM #CRMdev #dynamics #microsoft #api

    Designing powerful digital products is like crafting a captivating story! 📖 1️⃣ Every Page is the Beginning: Design with users in mind, considering their entry point and context. Just like a TV show recaps past episodes, each page should remind users why they're here. Changes in the process? Provide clear context to guide even the most seasoned users. 2️⃣ Mad Max - Center Framed: Imagine your web journey as a Mad Max movie – keep the focus! Quick clicks between pages should feel natural. Maintain flow continuity for a smooth user experience. Objects in your design have actions – make them obvious. Users are editors; help them navigate by creating unique experiences on each page. 3️⃣ Continuity Between Pages: Each web page is a new film, with changing plots but consistent characters. Like Batman movies, users should recognize elements without needing a tutorial. Implicit understanding is key – users shouldn't need explanations with every page. Think Batman – you always know his backstory! 4️⃣ Final Take-Aways: Multiple paths lead to the same destination. Users march to their own beat; don't expect them to follow your script. Design for flexibility; users should seamlessly start from any point. Introduce new elements with context; keep users from guessing halfway through. Remember, users are the heroes of their journeys – design for an engaging and exciting experience at every click! 💻 #thinkingbig #UXdesign #UIdesign #appdesign #appdevelopment #softwaredevelopment #userexperience #UXtip #productdesign #productdevelopment #creative #development #developmentagency #jobsintech #techindustry #canada #charlottetown #research #productresearch #userresearch #usabilitytest #usertest #testing

    Creating valuable content for your digital products begins with understanding your audience and their objectives. Content generated without careful consideration tends to be needlessly lengthy. In the realm of content planning and writing, formatting and structuring are intertwined. Formatting guarantees content predictability and scanability, while structuring establishes an organizational approach for efficient content delivery. Prioritize strategic content structuring before implementing formatting to ensure logical and coherent presentation. A well-designed content structure aids users in forming a clear mental model of the page, making it easier for them to navigate your content. Here are 5 formatting techniques for your content: ✅ Summaries: Using a summary of your content gives your users the key points from your information and allows them to decide if your content is relevant to them or not quickly. ✅ Callouts: A callout refers to a paragraph that is formatted to stand out from the rest of the body text. Callouts leverage visual weight to attract readers’ attention. ✅ Bullet points: They support scanning, emphasize key points, and reveal relationships among items. Bullet points can be paired with in-page links to serve as a table of contents for the page. ✅ Bolding and highlighting key points: Bolding and highlighting should be used to call attention to critical information. ✅ Helpful visuals: Using visuals helps break up walls of text and diversify the content layout, allowing eyes to rest from reading. Want to learn more about formatting your content? Check out this article by the NNgroup here: https://buff.ly/3UcaLSA #thinkingbig #UXdesign #UIdesign #appdesign #appdevelopment #softwaredevelopment #userexperience #UXtip #productdesign #productdevelopment #creative #development #developmentagency #jobsintech #techindustry #canada #charlottetown #contentwriting #content #websitedesign #webdesign

    When life presents us with choices, we often find ourselves caught in the tug-of-war between two seemingly opposing options. It’s like being stuck at a crossroads, unsure whether to go left or right. But what if I told you that this binary either/or thinking might not be the best approach. Our tendency to view things in black and white limits our perspective and inhibits creativity. Surprisingly a list of pros and cons isn’t going to take us far in figuring out the best way to go. The solution lies in understanding that there are new ways of thinking that unlock innovation by embracing the nuances between that black-and-white perspective. 🧐 Read our article about embracing the grey and breaking free from binary thinking here: https://buff.ly/3U81rPI #thinkingbig #UXdesign #UIdesign #appdesign #appdevelopment #softwaredevelopment #userexperience #UXtip #productdesign #productdevelopment #creative #development #developmentagency #jobsintech #techindustry #canada #charlottetown

    We know, team meetings suck. But what if they didn’t have to? 💩 The key to facilitating a good team meeting can be broken down into 4 key elements. Master these and you’ll have your team members asking when your next meeting is! 📌 Objective: Clearly define the purpose of your meeting. Determine your team’s desired goals and outcomes from the meeting, whether they’re big or small. 📌 Agenda: Create a meeting agenda. This structure will keep you organized and help you follow up your meeting with action items once it’s over, providing clarity and accountability from your team. 📌 Engagement: Avoid delivering monologues during team meetings, as active engagement is key to a successful gathering. Foster an environment where team members actively participate, and ensure that everyone remains present and attentive. 📌 Details: Consider the timing of your meetings and carefully select attendees. Strategic planning of when and who participates is just as pivotal as crafting a well-thought-out agenda and objectives. Do you run amazing meetings? Share your meeting tips with us! 📢 #thinkingbig #appdesign #appdevelopment #softwaredevelopment #websitedevelopment #development #agile #backlog #productbacklog #agileteam #sprintplanning #scrummaster

    We love using the game-changing feature in C# 12 - the Primary Constructor! You can define a constructor directly in the class declaration, making your code cleaner and more concise. 🤓 It's a game-changer for defining immutable types. But here's the catch - while it's a great step forward, the compiler doesn't enforce parameter immutability. 😬 Fear not! Here are two solutions: Solution 1: Using a read-only field. This involves creating a read-only field with the same name as the parameter and assigning the parameter value to the field. A bit of boilerplate, but effective. Solution 2: Enter the stage, Roslyn analyzer! You can use Meziantou. Analyzer to catch cases where a parameter is being assigned. Once installed, the rule MA0143 will report all assignments to primary constructor parameters in your project or usages as ref or out parameters.     Our TB crew is chalked full of talented folks doing cool things. Have you heard of @freefromtheharbour ? Brianne Savage and Meryn Avery are two best friends from the Maritimes who will be rowing 3000 miles across the Atlantic Ocean in 2025. They are set to be the first all-Canadian female pair ever to attempt the crossing and are raising money for the Marine Animal Response Society along the way. 🐳 To raise money and awareness for their campaign, they are hosting a screening of the documentary, Losing Sight of Shore, a film about four women whose journey to row across the Pacific Ocean inspired Brianne and Meryn to do it themselves. Join them on Sunday, February 11th to learn more about the extreme sport of ocean rowing and meet the team! You can learn more about their endeavour and follow their journey at https://buff.ly/4b5uOZ6 #worldstoughestrow #worldstoughestrowatlantic #oceanrowing #atlanticcampaigns

    How can Service Design help my organization? Service Design can help your organization by placing your users at the center of your strategy, fostering innovation, improving efficiency, and creating a more adaptable and user-centered product. By blending your user’s needs with your organization’s, you can truly take your product to the next level. How does it work? 🗺 Discovery: This phase allows us to better understand your users, their needs and how they work within the context of your organization’s needs. 🔧 Prototyping: During this time we take those requirements and needs and turn them into visual solutions. 👍 Validation: Once we have prototypes, we need to validate our designs with your users. It’s important to note that these phases are iterative! Taking an iterative approach allows us to prototype and validate your solutions continuously until we reach a final design that meets all of your user’s needs and organization’s requirements. Want to learn more about how Service Design can take your organization to the next level?
